title-group.article-title: Infection prevention and control commissioning toolkit: guidance and information for nursing and commissioning staff in England

abstract.p: Against a backdrop of system redesign in the NHS, the Infection Prevention Society and Royal College of Nursing have collaborated to produce a toolkit to support the implementation and use of infection prevention indicators as part of the quality assurance processes in the commissioning and contracting cycles. The toolkit is presented in this article.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Reducing healthcare associated infection (HCAI) remains high on the Governments safety and quality agenda. Since 2008 there has been a legal requirement on all healthcare and social care providers, including NHS organisations, to implement The Health and Social Care Act 2008, Code of Practice for the NHS on the prevention and control of healthcare-associated infections and related guidance. Other drivers for change, while not exhaustive, may include:

list-item.p: Care Quality Commission registration
Monitor’s compliance framework 2012/13 (Monitor, 2012)
Commissioning for quality and innovation (CQUIN)
The operating framework for the NHS in England (Department of Health, 2011)
Compliance with National Health Service Litigation Authority criteria
Health building notes and health technical memorandums/choice frameworks for local policies and procedures (CFPP)
Quality innovation productivity and prevention (QIPP) initiatives
National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) standards or quality statements

sec.p: The toolkit provides an overarching framework to help meet the challenge of reducing and sustaining reduction of HCAIs. It has been developed to support emerging commissioning organisations (commissioning support units or Clinical Commissioning Group [CCG]) in England to ensure that the structures, objective setting, monitoring and governance arrangements and resources for the prevention, control and reduction of HCAI are in place. As health and social care commissioning develops, it is essential that processes are in place to ensure the smooth transfer of commissioning authority from one organisation to another, and that duties and accountabilities in relation to reducing HCAIs are maintained without any detriment to patients or the quality of NHS service provision.

sec.title: Goals and aspirations – zero incidence of avoidable HCAI
Expectation of commissioning organisations
sec.p: Commissioners and providers of health and social care do not accept that HCAI is an inevitable part of, or an acceptable risk related to, health or social care. Commissioning organisations will support providers, while holding them to account for their performance with regards to surveillance of infections, and the implementation and sustained improvement of infection control practices and procedures to reduce HCAI.

In pursuit of the aspiration for zero incidence of avoidable HCAI, commissioning teams will systematically review local objectives across the organisations from which they commission services. This will include the review of surveillance data to monitor progress against nationally set trajectories for specific organisms and other agreed performance indicators.
All commissioning organisations are obliged to be sufficiently assured that all services, commissioned or contracted by them or on their behalf, are compliant with:

list-item.p: National Health Service Litigation Authority risk management standards
Reduction of HCAIs in line with nationally set objectives
Reporting of deaths where a HCAI is noted on a death certificate according to local policy and procedures
Ensuring lessons learned from any associated Root Cause Analysis (RCA) are completed in a timely way.
Contractual requirements relating to quality standards, NICE guidelines and other National Policies
Care Quality Commission (CQC) requirements (outcome 8). Notably if concerns are identified by the CQC it can lead to regulatory enforcement activities, including suspension of services.

sec.title: Expectations of provider organisations
sec.p: There is a legal requirement on all provider organisations to implement standards as required by the Code of Practice for the NHS on the Prevention and Control of HCAIs and related guidance (Department of Health, 2010a), which is integral to Care Quality Commission registration and ongoing compliance.
This toolkit emphasises the following requirements expected of provider organisations. They must:

list-item.p: be registered with the CQC to provide care that meets the requirements of the Code of Practice (Department of Health, 2010a)

have their own local infection prevention and control (IPC) strategy and assurance framework that reflects the their local commissioning organisations HCAI reduction plan, contractual requirements and provides evidence of their compliance with the Code of Practice (Department of Health, 2010a)

undertake assessments of their compliance with the Code of Practice (Department of Health, 2010a), at intervals agreed with the commissioning organisation. Compliance reports are submitted to the provider board for internal assurance and the commissioning organisation for external assurance

actively engage with the processes for HCAI/IPC performance and quality monitoring and are active members of any relevant cluster health economy infection prevention group (or other forums as appropriate)

sec.title: Guide to using the IPC commissioning indicators
sec.p: The Infection Prevention Society (IPS) and Royal College of Nursing (RCN) have developed the toolkit for existing and emerging commissioning organisations to support the commissioning of IPC along with the development and implementation of the commissioning framework in practice. The toolkit consists of a basket of indicators for consideration in the commissioning contract and an example of a local HCAI reduction plan.

It is recognised that some organisations may be more highly developed in their measuring and reporting of indicators than others, however, there should be a common aim across the commissioning board to standardise these where possible, while fostering additional opportunities for quality improvement at local level. Commissioners of health and social care require provider organisations to assure clean environments and safe practices to prevent HCAIs This assurance process should not seek to mirror other compliance or regulation requirements, moreover it should seek to affirm assurance by focussing on improvements needed, based on local requirements. Ideally this should be a shared process between commissioners and providers, with the overall joint aim of improving patient safety.

sec.title: Indicators
sec.p: Indicators help organisations to understand, compare, predict outcome and improve care. They should align contractual requirements to compliance with the Operating Framework for the NHS in England 2012–2013 (Department of Health, 2011) and be used to assist the delivery of the Public Health outcomes Framework (Department of Health, 2012b). Indicators should reflect requirements to implement best practice guidance set at national, regional and local levels to ensure the priorities for infection prevention are in the contracts. This toolkit presents the indicators in the format of the national contract (Table 1), to enable users to lift detail and place it into individual provider contracts. Note that this can be adapted for inclusion in social care contracts.

sec.p: In effect, each provider should have its own unique set of indicators and information schedule requirements to facilitate the robust assurance of performance required for IPC for the specific provider. The information schedule can be used as a ‘softer’ option; if the commissioner chooses to place one of the currently suggested indicators into the information schedule, they could replace the threshold requirement to ‘expectation’; thereby clearly stating that (and agreeing) the standard required. This approach will assist in the event that the information supplied within the schedule does not yield the level of assurance required of good Infection Prevention & Control (IPC) standards.

sec.title: Example of a local HCAI plan
sec.p: The (insert name of organisation) Cluster/Clinical Commissioning Group is committed to reducing the risk of HCAI as a key priority. The prevention and control of infection lies at the heart of patient safety, quality patient care, good management, governance and effective clinical practice.

The purpose of this HCAI plan is to outline the (insert organisation name) approach to the prevention and control of HCAI for the period (insert date) and to propose an agreed plan for the future new commissioning structures and arrangements.

The framework is designed to establish ownership of IPC at all levels throughout the organisations served by and accountable to the cluster/commissioning board. It supports a co-ordinated approach to the prevention and control of infection across all areas of responsibility. All providers will be expected to have in place annual programmes of work to ensure that standards and objectives are met according to agreed contractual indicators and national and local objectives for HCAI. This activity will be monitored on a locally agreed basis through formal reporting mechanisms established through the integrated quality teams and contract and performance monitoring systems. As the changing NHS welcomes any competent providers, incorporation of quality standards for infection prevention and HCAI through all levels of the commissioning and contractual process is essential.

The overarching purpose of the IPC commissioning role is to ensure the IPC element of patient safety, quality and experience is embedded within the commissioning process. The four main requirements to effectively commission for IPC include:

list-item.p: Development and leadership of the health and social care economy
Contracting (including setting clear expectations of achievement, e.g. compliance with the code of practice for IPC)
Performance monitoring against the contract (gaining assurance)
Organisational accountability

sec.title: Development and leadership of the health and social care economy

p.italic: Aim: To support the above key requirements and all healthcare providers to develop and own a collaborative approach to the prevention and management of HCAIs.

list-item.p: Establishing a health-economy-wide IPC network group (to aspire to a health and social care economy collaborative meeting, with sign up from CEOs and Directors)

Develop an IPC strategy based on joint strategic needs assessment, which is supported by and agreed across the whole health economy. This in turn will support individual provider organisation IPC strategies, and sits as part of the overarching Quality and Safety Strategy for the commissioning organisation.
In collaboration with CCGs develop systems that are fit for purpose and which will support delivery of the HCAI/safety agenda

Agree an IPC structure that will support providers to comply with the code of practice (own strategy, own assurance framework, risk assessment and work programmes, with assurance reports to the provider board to demonstrate compliance with the code of practice)
To identify local needs, develop capabilities and ensure capacity with all providers to aspire to a common IPC vision and goals

Commissioners engaging with social care to assist in their attainment of, and compliance with, the code of practice (while the legal responsibility lies with local authorities, the expertise lies within health, and commissioning organisations have an intrinsic responsibility to the whole population)

Commissioners, through the health economy network group will initiate and lead on the implementation of national/regional and local programmes in line with the NHS outcomes framework 2012/13, public health outcomes framework and adult social care outcomes framework, e.g.
MRSA screening
National HCAI surveillance programmes
Saving lives/essential steps
Sharing of learning of findings from root cause analysis of HCAI
Antibiotic stewardship
Decontamination strategy
Long-term conditions and premature death owing to communicable diseases

p.italic: Aim: To ensure national and local IPC standards are set at the correct level and included in contracts with provider organisations.

list-item.p:
When establishing IPC standards for providers due regard must be paid to the following:
Code of practice for IPC
Department of Health operating frameworks (NHS, public health and social care)
Current Strategic Health Authority (SHA) commissioning framework
Outcome documents (old vital signs)
National and regional standards
Local priorities
Ensure requirements for providers are included in contracts, as a minimum to state the need for registration with the CQC, and compliance with the code of practice

Ensure there are service specifications for IPC and specific/relevant key performance indicators (KPIs) and quality indicators within the provider contracts. As a minimum these will reflect the national objectives within the operating framework and other national mandatory policies – see Appendix 1
Support engagement with quality improvement initiatives as appropriate through CQUIN development
Ensure infection prevention input into all new contracts, services and pathways as they are developed. This will be achieved through a series of quality gateways in the programme development pathway
Ensure that there is IPC input to IPC-related contracts, such as cleaning, planned preventive measures (PPMs) and waste.

sec.title: Performance monitoring (gaining assurance)
sec.p: Aim: To monitor performance against all shared objectives and KPIs from all providers.

list-item.p:
To participate in performance monitoring and quality assurance arrangements for each provider through:
Attendance at provider infection prevention committees and review meetings with provider IPC leads as locally agreed
Regular formal HCAI performance monitoring meeting with contract management staff
Input into the overarching contract quality meeting/clinical quality review groups
Receipt of regular infection prevention/HCAI dashboards from providers
Un-announced inspection visits

Ensure there is appropriate IPC expertise within the commissioning organisation to interpret received data from providers. To interrogate information given and to ascertain whether the information provides the required assurance.

For independent contractors, it is essential that the commissioning IPC team is part of internal performance monitoring arrangements for primary care (e.g. Performance Management Group). It is through this mechanism that the environmental audits that are undertaken to assess environmental fitness for purpose can be feed into the overarching performance framework

In addition, IPC should feature in the commissioning framework about fitness to practice as commissioning decisions are made about the transfer of care from secondary to primary (e.g. is the environment fit for purpose)
Engage with primary care contracting to develop a robust assurance of infection prevention practice across primary care providers as the cluster processes evolve

p.italic: Aim: To ensure IPC is embedded and robust board accountability/assurance is demonstrated.

list-item.p: IPC is an integral part of the (insert name of organisation) Cluster/Commissioning Group internal quality and safety monitoring system

The (insert name of organisation) Cluster has a strategic plan and operational plan for reducing HCAI and improving infection prevention practices, which takes into account the changing NHS architecture
Accurate information is reported into the organisational framework and reported on the quality dashboard and all other relevant performance matrix and shared with CCGs.

Information will be monitored monthly by the infection prevention and integrated quality teams. Formal Director of Infection Prevention (DIPC) reports analysing quality and performance, action plans and exceptions will be made to the approved committee within the commissioning organisation and (insert name of cluster) Cluster Board at a locally agreed frequency. An annual report would provide a summary of activity, assurance and risks to the board.
The cluster will contribute to any SHA assurance review preparation papers and provide the SHA Board with commentary in preparation for questions)
IPC commissioning arrangements are embedded into the commissioning organisation’s governance processes.
There is an escalation process in place. HCAI is added, where necessary to the corporate risk register
Infection prevention is an integral part of the capital programme for new builds and refurbishments (to ensure IPC standards are met and premises are fit for purpose)
To be part of the emergency planning process
